reviewText: The movie deals with a lot of social issues, a few being poverty, race, classicism, and the lack of a formal education. This film setting is somewhere deep south; I'm basing this on the physical environment and confederate flags that are visible from time to time. Joe is actually a good guy with a short attention span attach to very short fuse. Joe is southern trailer-park trash who have just cross path with poor white trash; A fifteen year boy who was born with 4 strikes. Joe takes the audience on roller coaster through the backwoods to save this  young man not only from himself but from a seriously dysfunctional family. This is something a little different for Mr Cage but I like a lot.  two Thumbs up for JOE!!!!
I can't believe the negative comments on this movie. Probably Nicholas Cage's best ever. If you like dark, gritty movies set in the South, don't miss this.

Joe (Nicolas Cage) is your basic good man with a low snap point. He works a crew under the table for the logging company. He has his vices and everyone in this small rural community knows him. Gary (Tye Sheridan) is a fifteen year old "boy left behind" who has issues with his drunken lazy father incredibly portrayed by Gary Poulter. Joe attempts to help the boy out without getting involved, while helping out others...everyone but himself.

The film moves slow to build character and background material. The gritty drama far outweighs the action aspect. This is a film that reminded me of "Winterbone" where we see a piece of a Southern rural community sliced open.

Parental Guide: F-bomb. Brief sex and nudity (Sue Rock?)

Directed by David Gordon Green, Joe opens with a teenage son chastising his alcoholic father.  The decrepit patriarch has once again misbehaved and brought trouble to the doorstep of himself and his family, forcing them to drift to another town.  The father hits his son and teeters into the distance; there, a group of men emerge and beat him.  The son leaves the scene as the sound of landed blows echo.  This grim scene sets the stage for the overall film, a heavy Southern-Gothic meditation on failure, family, and masculinity.

The aforementioned son is played by Tye Sheridan, who, between this film, The Tree of Life, and last year's Mud, has mastered the art of playing Southern lads on the verge of transitioning from earnest childhood to hardened knowledge of the adult world and its perils.  The bastard of a father is played by the late Gary Poulter, a real-life bipolar drifter and former G.I. cast on the street.  Poulter received a terminal cancer diagnosis shortly after the end of the production and later drowned in a small pool of water, inebriated.  (This knowledge only intensifies the impact of a brutal, lived-in nonprofessional performance.)  And the great Nicolas Cage delivers one of his most rewarding performances as the title character, an introverted ex-convict who heads a tree-poisoning outfit and becomes an improbable mentor to the Sheridan character.

Green, who here laces the grand visual poetry of his debut George Washington with arsenic and old-fashioned suspense, gives the central trio of characters time and space to reveal themselves, and they emerge as flesh-and-blood characters who are at the same time almost mythological in their sunburned, forgotten-by-society-at-large melancholy.  Cage, always existing on the line separating the A-list movie stars from the wild-eyed character actors, is the perfect choice to play a man whose day-to-day existence in an exercise in extreme self-control.  Joe is a bit of a bastard, and he has a fire inside him, yet he is also tender and desperate to be the best version of himself given the circumstances of his existence.  It is a delight to see Cage portray this internal conflict.  I am not sure any other high-profile celebrity performer could do it so well.  The film in general is highly entertaining and involving, however foreboding and profane.  There are points which honestly invite a reaction of, "Christ, can they shoehorn one more filthy, larger-than-life, mean-spirited character into this crazy film?," but it is always a fleeting response because the characters and their hard-edged arcs are just too riveting to turn away from.

(Minor Spoilers) Only about 20 minutes into the film, you start to realize "Joe" (Nicolas Cage, whose fans will not be disappointed) and 15-year-old "Gary" (Tye Sheridan) have quite complicated and dark lives.  In fact, the director takes you into a world rarely seen on film (complete with a deer-gutting scene and extreme dog-fighting violence), as ex-con Joe hires young Gary and his abusive Dad as manual laborers and eventually becomes Gary's protector, after witnessing Gary's home life firsthand.  But, alas, maybe it's Joe who needs protection of his own from his impulsive and explosive ways.  As in "Sling Blade," it's quite the challenge for film-makers to combine the gloomy and occasionally disturbing subject matter presented here with tenderness and emotion.  And in that way, the presentation of "Joe" as a film, though with formidable performances, doesn't quite hit its mark; it's like those Olympians you see just missing out on a medal by coming in 4th place.

As I watched this movie it engrossed me into its world of abandonment.  Everyone in this movie has been forgotten, left behind, and given up on.  Every life is a product of seeming hopelessness.  The protagonist, Joe (Nic Cage), is an ex-con who's chosen to keep his head low, work a day's wage, and move forward in the midst of an isolated, lonely life.  He passes his time in sordid ways, though at his core he longs for something more.

In Gary (Tye Sheridan), Joe finds a troubled teen who is a mirror of himself as a young man, on the cusp of giving up, and drowning in pain, anger, and violence.  One of the most poignant scenes is when he and Joe go out the an old abandoned ship yard and practice smiling through their faces of pain.  This is a snapshot of the movie.  As Gary is faced with the pure evil of his father, and the sordid relationships he has with alcohol and others, Gary is at the crossroads where Joe took the wrong turn earlier in life.  The movie portrays Joe as an anti-hero who chooses sacrifice over self-preservation, redemption over ruin.

While the movie unfortunately promotes violence and vengeance as the way to atone, it also shows that we must fight violence with love, selfishness with sacrifice, and evil with good.  While these themes have been explored numerous times over, the way Director/Producer David Gordon Green tells it is so rich and raw that it deeply resonates with your own heart, all the times you were left, all the moments of isolation, all the anger and hopelessness it produced, it echoes inside.  The movie takes place in the contemporary South, but its real setting is the human heart.

There are probably many more cogent reviews of this movie.  Here's mine, for what it's worth.  I just finished watching this, on Amazon Prime.  I didn't know what to expect, not having heard of it, and not being a fan of Nicolas Cage.  This film lured me in, first with a light-heartedness, then in a dirty and grimy way.  But the characters were real, as real as people I have known.  And the acting: again, was it acting?  The kid, played by Tye Sheridan, was authentic as it gets.  He is the soul around whom the rest of this world revolves.  Joe is the main character, a hard-working, hard-drinking, short-tempered guy with a good heart, providing jobs for the lower class workers that reside in the rural area.  We are soon made aware of the extreme lower edge of his social peers, the local whores, the "poor white trash", the criminal element festering just under the surface.  The sets used here evoke the realism of extreme poverty, hopelessness and moral decay.  Add to this the local law enforcement who are seemingly out to get those who have already spent time in the "big jail", as Gary calls it, which includes Joe.  The movie moves along slowly at first, then increasingly and naturally builds to a climax, once we are fully committed to life as Joe knows it.  As I watched I felt the need to pause the movie and go wash my hands, or throw up.  I could smell the cigarette smoke and the dog s***, and feel the blood and the dirtiness of existence there.  I laughed at some things, and could believe I was with Joe and Gary drinking and driving and feeling good and normal.  I also felt shock at the violence that was just underneath the surface of all these people, and the connection it could possibly have in me.  The cinematography is masterful, and the score is appropriate, especially toward the end.  Nicolas Cage as Joe delivers a wonderful understated performance.  Tye Sheridan is amazing as Gary.  His father is played so real it's scary.  I recommend this film, to be watched alone, late at night, for the full impact.

In this remake of a 1970 film by the same name, Nicholas Cage plays Joe, an ex-con and unlikely hero to a fifteen year old boy. The story is called Joe, and you'll figure out why by the end, but to be honest, I saw this film more as a coming of age story, with the majority of the focus on Gary (Tye Sheridan). Gary's family is difficult to say the least, both his parents are drug addicts, and it's up to him to earn a living to support his sister. One day while out in the woods, he comes across Joe, a man who owns a lumber company and persuades him to give him a job. Gary is a hard worker who comes to see his boss as more of a father figure than his own father, and when things get bad, he's turns to Joe for help. Joe is no saint though, as he has his own criminal past and is reluctant to get involved. This is one of these really dark, slow moving dramas, where everything may or may not be important to the story. The real action is spaced out, but when something happens, the intensity is off the charts. This film is very similar to, Winter's Bone, which also had a young lead trying to save her siblings. While Tye Sheridan is not Jennifer Lawrence, his more quiet demeanor makes him more likable in the eyes of the viewer. Sheridan is a kid who came out of nowhere to star in the independent film, Mud, and since then has become known for making these super dark, intense films, where he plays a quiet, reserved character that one can't help but root for. Nicholas Cage is equally as good in a role that is more dramatic than most of things he's done lately. That being said, Cage still has it and together with Sheridan make for one of the most interesting and unique films I've seen all year. The story and even the trailer seem to be a little dull, most people will look at this film and see it as too slow and dramatic, and at first, I thought so too, but as the film progresses it just gets better and better, ascending to the level of a must see movie.

Joe is one of the messiest, tangled, depraved, heartbreaking and powerful films I've seen. There are harsh moments that made me look away, and there are stunningly powerful shots that had me glued to the screen.

Im a fan of character dramas and I often enjoy coming-of-age stories, and Joe excels at both. The characters are richly explored (in their glory and depravity) and painfully believable. We live in a pretty messed-up world, and while we often turn in our face away in reality, this film shoots you straight. From the alcoholic, abusive , deadbeat father to the violent, lascivious, hardworking Joe, these are real people. Analyzing the film, its important to not call evil good, and I think it avoids doing that quite well. With the flawed Joe being the role model for young Gary, we see some powerfully beautiful contrast between the two, and also the painful reminder of how our seemingly small influence can affect others deeply.

The acting here is jaw-dropping. This is Nicolas Cage at his absolute best, the late Gary Poulter who was himself a homeless alcoholic, pulls off an incredible performance as the dad, and Tye Sheridan is simply one of the best out there. Despite his downfall into low, cheesy films, Cage proves once again here that he is an incredibly adaptable actor and he nails the complex role of Joe. Sheridans performance is flawless. His ability to handle super complex and very difficult roles is incredible, and in every film I've seen him in, I have yet to doubt one second of his performance. With talent like this, hes only rising in the industry and I hope he isn't like so many who have been destroyed by it.

My four stars are not for recommendation or content. This is a harsh film that shows a little more than is necessary. But for the ideas and portrayal, Joe knows the story it is telling and conveys it exceptionally well. Everyone in the film industry seems to claim that story is king, but the films produced don't always live up to the teaching. In telling a great story, Im passionate about seeing characters that are real and well-explored, good or bad, and that is the greatest strength of this film. There aren't many good guys, and as such, its a slightly depressing film to watch, but if you choose to go into the darkness in Joe, may its subtle, powerful moments inspire you and the darkness challenge you to live in the light.

The movie is overwrought at a few moments...hard to find films that aren't these days. This film is a real "slice-of-life" in that it shows the real poverty of some Southern families in the present era.  Tye Sheridan handles his character so convincingly and the viewer's heart bleeds as a result of this.  Nicholas Cage's character "Joe" is even more complicated because it reveals a man caught in the middle, i.e. between the law enforcement's inability to handle the many incidents and Joe's inability to intervene in someone else's family disputes.  The boy's abusive and alcoholic father is at the bottom of everyone's troubles, coupled with a town troublemaker's conniving.  The plot of the film is good but slow to at the beginning.  Once matters start to get out of hand, it picks up.  It was difficult for me to understand how people in this small Texas town all had revolvers and that they had real shootouts with other people.  On top of that, after being wounded, Joe digs out a slug in his shoulder instead of going to a hospital or even calling in the local police.  Not being from Texas, I cannot really say if this normal life or not in that State.  It's a great film for Nicholas Cage fans and Tye Sheridan is an up and coming young actor whose career is worth watching.

RELEASED IN 2013 and directed by David Gordon Green, Joe chronicles events in the heart of Texas when a goodhearted-but-flawed ex-con, Joe (Nicolas Cage), befriends a 15 year-old poor kid (Tye Sheridan) from a dysfunctional family headed by a hopeless alcoholic (Gary Poulter). Ronnie Gene Blevins plays Joes rival while Adriene Mishler plays Joes maybe babe. Aj Wilson McPhaul is on hand as the likable police chief.

This is a southern gothic crime drama with a gritty melancholy mood similar to Mud (2013) and Winters Bone (2010). The guy who plays the kids dirtbag father was actually a homeless drunk who pursued acting in his youth. While he looks like hes about 68 years-old, he was actually only 53 and died on the streets of Austin a couple of months after filming stopped.

The movie depicts the ugly side of rural trash (aka rednecks) and is so downbeat some find it disgusting. Also, the film might seem sloppy story-wise, but thats because it respects the intelligence of the viewer to read in between the lines. If you can look past these issues, there are thematic gems to mine and there are occasional glimmerings of light.

THE FILM RUNS 1 hour & 57 minutes and was shot in rural areas outside Austin, Texas (Bastrop, Taylor & Lockhart). WRITERS: Gary Hawkins wrote the script based on the novel by Larry Brown.

GRADE: B-

Great movie, great acting. One of those movies you can't believe it took so long for you to discover. It's a shame it wasn't seen by much more people when it was released. Do yourself a favor and see this excellent independent film!

The screenplay seems intent on encapsulating American stereotypes and stereotypical behaviors, with strange consequences.  For example, it's fine for Joe to visit the local bordello where young (if presumably legal) women satisfy the rough carnal urges of local average guys (we get graphic illustration of this in one scene), but we are to be outraged when a young (and not legal) teen is being sold off in the back of the van to another lusty dude.  Swift and capital punishment for that, meted out vigilante style. Why, if only they'd waited a few more years, she could have worked in the bordello!  It's all reflects so badly on Hollywood's take on coarser side of our culture.

This is the best Nicholas Cage has ever been. Joe is a slow burn, dark, and mature drama about a friendship blossoming between a man with a dark and violent past and a young and enthusiastic boy and it's one of my favorite Cage movies of all time.
